address.addrLine: Office of Digital Collections and Research (DCR), University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742

availability.p: Baroness Elsa von Freytag-Loringhoven's poetry is printed here with the support of the University of Maryland Libraries. Permission to reproduce images of Freytag-Loringhoven's manuscripts has also been generously granted by the libraries.

This poem and manuscript drafts are available from this site for demonstration purposes only. Though the intellectual property of Elsa von Freytag-Loringhoven is in the public domain, all annotations and editorial commentary are copyrighted. They may not be reproduced without explicit permission from the copyright holder. For copyright information, please contact Tanya Clement.

note.p: The images are JPEGS derived from TIFFS scanned at 600 dpi.

Draft clusters of this poetic event may be found on microfilm and in three folders in the Elsa von Freytag-Loringhoven papers archived within Special Collections at the University of Maryland, College Park.
Firstling (Erstling, He): circa 1923-1924; Reel 4, Frames 54-65; series 3, box 2, folder 3
Liebe; Sonnsang: undated; Reel 4, Frame 472; series 3, box 2, folder 67
Lilac Old (Alter Flieder); He; Pfingsten: undated; Reel 4, Frames 479 and 481; series 3, box 2, folder 68
Pfingst (Fanfare, Pfingstjubel, Pfingsten; Erstling; Ritter in Gold Verzieter RÃ¼stung): circa 1923-1924; Reel 5, Frame 244-246, series 3, box 3, folder 23
For more information, please see the Finding Aid at http://hdl.handle.net/1903.1/1501.

sourceDesc.p: Encoded documents and images are derived from manuscripts in the Papers of Elsa von Freytag-Loringhoven in Special Collections at the University of Maryland, College Park, Libraries.

Each version and note is numbered according to the order in which it appears in the folders in special collections and in the order that they appear on a given manuscript page, from left to right and top to bottom (e.g. versions 1.1-1.6 all appear on the first manuscript page in the first folder related to this complex).

editorialDecl.p: DTD constructed from TEI P5 poetry base with tagsets for linking, figures, analysis, transcr, textcrit.

rdg.note: This whole version is lightly crossed out on the manuscript page. To increase legibility, we have chosen to show those words in the transcript that the Baroness deleted before she crossed out the entire version.

app.rdg: HAB DICH DICH LIEB DICH GEWONNEN -
Now I have come to love you
NUN SOHAB ICH DICH LIEB GEWONNEN
NUN HAB ICH DICH LIEB GEWONNEN
UND WIE NUN SO IST NUN ALLES VORBEI
Why is now all gone past
GLÜCK KLANG SPRANG RANG RANG ZERRONNEN -
WIE EIN GEBILD WIE EIN GEBILD ZERRONNEN
SIND DIE GLIEDER MIR SCHWER WIE BLEI

rdg.add: DIE DIE GLIEDER SIND SCHWER WIE VON BLEI

app.rdg: [My] limbs are as heavy as lead

rdg.note: These lines and words in English appear, all crossed out, at the bottom of a version of the poem in German. Their random order reflects a possible brainstorming cluster that can be associated with many versions within the general complex.

app.rdg: From the blood vessel tree the bitter
From the blood vessel tree the bitter
Es ist SO SEHR KALT IST ES DASS ICH ZITTRE
ES IST SO KALT BIN ICH DASS WON ICH ICH ZITTRE
So cold it is, I shudder

rdg.del: DREAM RANG PURRED SIFTED WALKED PAST

app.rdg: HERZ BRICHT AB IM LEIB IN DEM LEIB
Heart breaks off in my body
HERZ BRICHT AUS DEM VOM LEIB AB
MEIN DAS HERZ ERFRIERT VEREIST IM LEIB
The heart turns to ice in my body
My heart turns to ice inside [my body]

rdg.del: HAPPINESS SPRANG SCATTERED SPILLED RUNNING LEFT

app.rdg: IM MEINEM BLUT ADER NETZ - DAS BITTRE

rdg.note: This is one of the few notes that the Baroness adds in cursive. These additions only appear in this version.
This is one of the few notes that the Baroness adds in cursive. These additions only appear in this version.

app.rdg: OHN DICH EIN SONNENBLUT SCHEIN GESTALT -
ZITT'RE OHN DICH ZUM GRAB ICH

rdg.note: This is one of the few notes that the Baroness adds in cursive. These additions only appear in this version.

app.rdg: NUN HAB ICH DICH LIEB GEWONNEN
Now I have come to love you

rdg.note: The word "wart" may be a play on "wert" -- "icy / [you] were / [you] froze . . ." that Freytag-Loringhoven adapted later as a metaphor for "heart."

app.rdg: DASSDAS SO IST NUN ALLES VORBEI
SHONEThis is one of the few notes that the Baroness adds in cursive. These additions only appear in this version. AGONE
SOWN B F LUFF SH LUSH BLO
Red I you A possible reading of this line could be "Tomorrow [I] kiss you red again" but the Baroness is playing in this version with who is kissing whom.
IN IN MEINEM ARMEN ALL HAND
IN MEIN HANDFLÄCH TELLER GESCHIEHT WACHST

rdg.note: GOTT = MAN x WEIB = ALLEINS = ANFANG ?? NICHTS ALL WAS DAZWISCHEN ?? LIGHT DAS IST VOM ÜBEL. [This addition is discussed in the introduction and shown in Figure 8.

The small fragment at the bottom of the page is not a version of this poem:
GELD IST DASEIN [Money is Being]
GELD MUSS DASEIN [Money must be there]
ZUM DASEIN [for Being]
It continues with a variety of endings concerning death.

rdg.del: ICY IN SNOW ICE IN SNOW

app.rdg: THESE TWO POEMS ARE SAME. I LEAVE IT TO YOU - IF YOU WILL PRINT BOTH? WITH THAT
I CONSIDER IT SINGULAR STRONG ENOUGH - TO COUNTENANCE THE SHRIVELING OF THE HEART TO THE SEMBLANCE AND USELESS APENDIX APPENDIX OF THE HEART.

IT IS GREAT DIFFERENCE
IN SOUND AND MEANING.
IN ATTITUDE.

BLOWING IS ROMANTIC
BLOWN IS FACT
I THINK: BLOWN!
IT IS SAME POEM. PRINT BOTH - OR ONE OF THEM - WICHWHICH ONE - YOU MUST SELECT.

GLÜCK SPRANG SCHWANG VORBEI
TRÄUME -- BEGONNEN
GLÜCK TRAUM BEGONNEN

Happiness swung by
[Blissdreams]
Dreams begun
Happiness . . . begun

DJUNA - I SEND YOU THIS - YOU WILL SCARCELY RECOGNIZE IT - THE ENGLISH WAS SUCH MISSTEP THAT ONLY CAN HAPPEN HERE - IN GERMANY WHERE I AM FLUSTERED FRUSTRATED - BY PROFOUND SCARE - UNREST. WITH ALMOST SUPERHUMAN LABOR - MISERY - I FIXED IT - FOR I WAS ASHAMED - ANXIOUS. I CAN NOT LAST THUS LONG - DJUNA! AND YET - I HAVE NO MESSAGE - YET! A POEM LIKD THAT - THOUGH FAULTLESS NOW - SHOULD NOT COST ME SO DEAR! THE GERMAN - FIRST VERSION - ALWAYS WAS TOUCHING PATHETIC NAIV - FINISHED. WHAT IS INTERRESTINGINTERESTING ABOUT THE 2 TOGETHER- IS THEIR VAST DIFFERENCE OF EMOTION - TIME KNOWLEDGE - PAIN. THAT IS - WHY THEY SHOULD BE PRINTED TOGETHER.

FOR THEY ARE 1 + 2 THE SAME POEM - PERSON - SENTIMENT LIFE STRETCH BETWEEN ONE - DIVIDED - ASSEMBLED - DISSEMBLED. THE GERMAN ONE RIPE - EXPERIENCED - BITTER. THE GERMAN ONE IS RAW DEEP WOE OF CHILD - IN WHOMS VERY VERY VIOLENCE THUS NAIVE EXPRESSED - LINGERS BALM OF RECOVERY SENSIBLE - THE ENGLISH ONE - AS IS SUPERFLUOUS TO POINT OUT - IS GRIM - SOPHISTICATED.

YES DJUNA - IT IS THAT "WOEFULL WART" POOR DEAR SUFFERING FRIEND! I COULD BURST OUT LAUGHING - IF IT WERE NOT SO TRULY FIGURATIVE IN ITS VERY DISTORTION! FOR - THAT NOW - HERE - IS MY HEART. IT IS INDECENT TO BEHOLD.
HOW IS SWEET DEAR LITTLE SARAH FREEMAN?
SHE DID NOT WRITE. OH! KISS HER.
